text: BTW, I don't mean this to be a scold. Just part of the discussion. I've pretty much zapped "moderate" from my writing lexicon but I'm sure I've used "populist" a ton. It can be hard to boil a politician's entire political philosophy down to one adjective.
author: nickconfessore

text:
"Moderate" is sometimes used almost as an award bestowed.
"Populist" has become largely disconnected from its historical roots, and I'm not sure it conveys anything except for "vaguely folksy and notionally if not actually anti-establishment"
author: nickconfessore

text:
Two adjectives that all campaign reporters and editors ought to think carefully about when using -- and also think about what they intend to mean when used:
1) Populist
2) Moderate
(probably more than just those two, but they're on my mind lately)

author: nickconfessore

text:
For the folks asking me today if I still use Fb. 
I do have an account, though I've deleted most of my old pictures. I log in occasionally. But basically only use it for reporting.
I don't keep Facebook Inc. or Google apps on my phone with one exception.
And I use @DuckDuckGo.
author: nickconfessore

text:
The theory: Facebook is a walled garden where you and your friends and kids can safely hang out and talk and share pictures.
The reality: Facebook threw a raging kegger in the garden—and invited all their friends.
author: nickconfessore

text: On the *other* other hand, Facebook never asked your friends if they were cool with it. They argue that since your friends already shared that picture with you, they could show it to your friend through Bing.
author: nickconfessore

text: On the other hand, Facebook also acknowledges that these partnerships have raised user trust issues. And they are now winding all of them down.
author: nickconfessore

text: I.e., in this context, Bing or Spotify or a Russian search engine are effectively part of Facebook. They are delivering data to you -- such as data about your friends -- that you already could see on Facebook.
author: nickconfessore

text:
So what does Facebook say about all this? We had many long exchanges with the company, which provided a lot of useful context and information. 
The key argument: Facebook doesn't need explicit consent because these partners are all functionally extensions of Facebook itself.
author: nickconfessore

text: #5: Regulators let it happen. For almost the entire period Facebook had these data deals, it was under federal consent decree with the @FTC. Four former @FTC officials tell us they think the deals violate Facebook's consent decree.
author: nickconfessore

text: #4: Facebook was sloppy. At our prodding, Facebook found data partners it forgot it was giving your information to. And some of the partners we called said they didn't even know they were getting the data.
author: nickconfessore

text: #3: That's right. No one told you. Try finding these details in that endless privacy disclosure. The only sure way you can limit Facebook's corporate partners from gaining access to your info is by blocking everyone else. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/18/us/politics/facebook-data-sharing-deals.html …
author: nickconfessore

text: #2: Maybe you thought Cambridge Analytica was bad. But companies like Amazon and Microsoft got way more user data -- with way less disclosure. By privacy lights CA was a piker. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/18/us/politics/facebook-data-sharing-deals.html …
author: nickconfessore

text:
Yo I heard you like aggregation, so here are some takeaways from our latest Facebook investigation. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/18/us/politics/facebook-data-sharing-deals.html …
#1: Facebook deals in your data. They don't sell it -- but they found strategically superior ways to monetize your data w/partners.
author: nickconfessore

text:
These deals are different in significant respects from the access afforded app makers like the one working for Cambridge Analytica.
But in a broad sense they are not. 
Companies you may never have had a relationship with could see your stuff.
author: nickconfessore

text:
The Times obtained internal Facebook documents showing in intricate detail how Facebook allocated user data to “partner” companies, ranging from @Microsoft to @amazon to @Spotify and @Yahoo. 
The key deals were all active in 2017. Some remained in place until this year.
author: nickconfessore

text: EXCLUSIVE: Hundreds of pages of internal Facebook documents reveal how the company shared and traded data with other Silicon Valley giants—without telling its users.

text:
Two possible reasons for why government is less responsive to the policy preferences of low-income people is:
1) Poor people cannot afford to run and serve (or intern)
2) With fewer staff, Members are more dependent on moneyed interests and trade groups in policymaking.
author: nickconfessore

text:
Things the U.S. government can definitely afford, and for which there are good arguments in the broad public interest:
1) Subsidized D.C. housing and a higher salary for Members of Congress.
2) More and better-paid staff for Member offices.
3) Intern salaries.

Zuck can’t be fired because it’s his company.
Sandberg can’t be fired because Zuck can’t be fired and it would be a double standard.
So no one actually has to be held responsible except a guy who was already leaving.

text: The ICO notes that the companies had a close working relationship, but "we have no evidence that AIQ has been anything other than a separate legal entity" -- basically it was a frequent subcontractor for CA on projects, including in the U.S.
author: nickconfessore

text: The report also largely dismisses accusations that AIQ--a Canadian company set up to provide some services to Cambridge--was some kind of front or shell for Cambridge itself, perhaps to do secret or improper work for Leave.
author: nickconfessore

text: But ICO also debunks a few things. Notwithstanding a variety of contradictory statements from CA officials on the subject, the report states that Cambridge never did any actual work for http://Leave.EU .
author: nickconfessore

text:
It also seems that Cambridge made at least some attempt to delete Facebook data in its possession right after the ICO announced its investigation.
Nevertheless, ICO found that Cambridge in 2018 retained (at least) proprietary models based on the improperly obtained Facebook data.
author: nickconfessore

text: Worse: When the warrant was served, ICO investigators found "a number of disconnected and physically damaged servers." The suggestion is that Cambridge employees may have tried to destroy evidence.
author: nickconfessore

text: Cambridge itself was equally sloppy with the Facebook data it obtained. When the ICO executed a search warrant, it found passwords written on Post-it notes stuck to walls. They used personal email accounts to transfer data. They didn't encrypt transfers.
author: nickconfessore

text: Keep in mind: In 2014, Cambridge, via the contractor who built its Facebook app, was a small new political data firm and just one of a huge number of companies surfing Facebook's platform and harvesting user data.
author: nickconfessore

text:

text: Tomorrow I'll pick up with some behind-the-scenes moments from California, where my story (and Mactaggart's) ends.
author: nickconfessore

text: The Cambridge Analytica scandal scrambled the old playbook, in part because it indelibly associated Silicon Valley's lucrative data mining with -- fairly or not, Trump's victory. In California, Mactaggart's ballot initiative was suddenly very popular.
author: nickconfessore

text: The playbook: Argue that privacy rules are unnecessary because "no one cares." Or too technically difficult to implement. Or will make it hard to catch criminals. Or kill jobs. It worked--until California, and until Cambridge Analytica.
author: nickconfessore

text: He first tried to negotiate w/Facebook & Google. Mactaggart sat with both companies last year to discuss a compromise. A couple months later, they secretly started funding a campaign to crush him. Dems in California led the charge, using what had become a familiar playbook.
author: nickconfessore

text: Mactaggart had money, and passion, but no fixed idea about how to tackle privacy. He hooked up with a few privacy vets, including @JustinBrookman, @hoofnagle, and @ashk4n, who came on as a consultant. The lessons of Washington, Illinois, and other battles shaped their plan.
author: nickconfessore

text: Around the same time, in California, a Bay Area real estate developer named Alastair Mactaggart was getting interested in privacy issues, after dinner with a Google engineer who told him how scared people would be if they knew what Google knew about them.
author: nickconfessore

text: That lawmaker, Terry Link, has never commented publicly on his amendment, which was quickly withdrawn. But he spoke to @nytimes for the first time about what happened--contradicting @facebook's explanation:

text: Big Tech was arguably even more powerful in state capitols. In 2016, after a judge ruled that a Chicago man could sue Facebook, an Illinois lawmaker proposed amending the law behind the suit -- his own law, as @arstechnica, @TheVerge, and others reported at the time.

text: You quickly wind up with a very dense and complex web of judgments and calls. By comparison, applying conventional journalistic values -- truth, accuracy, the public interest -- is a lot more straightforward, though it does involve judgment calls.
author: nickconfessore

text: How narrowly are you defining wrongdoing? What counts as hacking? (Say "evidence of a crime" and you lose most of the Panama Papers/Paradise Papers. Is any government document okay, but not any private individual's papers? How do you define private individual?
author: nickconfessore

text: If you figure out criteria that make sense to you, I'll eagerly read. But I suspect the difficulty any of us have in articulating a journalistically sound alternative, even for the sake of argument, is meaningful.
author: nickconfessore

text: I'm interested in hearing Leah's counter-proposal. What rules or guidelines should journalists consider when presented with stolen information, particularly if they suspect it was sourced by foreign countries?
author: nickconfessore

text:
I don't use "liberal Twitter" disparagingly. It's just a shorthand. I don't think Liberal Twitter maps cleanly to Liberal Real World.
But, Brian and Chris, I'd listen to an argument for how to "consider and adapt," as you put it. Mostly I see the argument posed in the negative.
author: nickconfessore

text:
We *have* wrestled with it. I have personally wrestled with it. I've concluded that relying on basic journalistic principles is both the simplest and best way to handle these challenges.
Open to counterarguments, of course.
author: nickconfessore

author: nickconfessore

text:
I'll close with a thought experiment. If a hacker came to your paper in the summer of 2016 with Trump Tower's call logs, or stolen video of Mr. Trump in a Moscow hotel room, or copies of all of his son's e-mails, would you publish stories about them?
I think we know the answer.
author: nickconfessore

text: Perhaps not every story we published about the e-mails met the standard of newsworthiness. But I think almost all of them did. Virtually every news organization in America made the judgment we did about news value and the public interest, probably for similar reasons.
author: nickconfessore

text: E-mails separately stolen from the DNC revealed party officials' disdain for Bernie Sanders's and some evidence of efforts to sabotage his campaign--as well as an unprecedented inside look at the privileges of the elite Democratic donor class.
author: nickconfessore

text: The e-mails revealed information that illuminated our understanding of Clinton, her political and financial relationships, her struggles to find a central message, the factionalism that undermined her campaign operation.
author: nickconfessore

text: A lot of people will argue that the Podesta and DNC e-mails don't reveal anything as significant or scandalous as, e.g., the civilian death toll in Iraq. That's probably right. But that doesn't mean they didn't contain newsworthy information.
author: nickconfessore

text: It's always worth trying to air a source's motives. As evidence of Julian Assange's symbiotic relationship with Russian interests piled up, e.g., NYT's Jo Becker wrote a deep investigation of those links. (She shared a Pulitzer for that story and others.)
author: nickconfessore

text: WikiLeaks was a source for many such documents and stories: The Iraq War logs provided by Chelsea Manning, for example, and secret U.S. diplomatic cables. This journalism was applauded by many on the political left (and often attacked on the political right).
author: nickconfessore

text: We published private financial documents from the Panama Papers and the Paradise Papers, even in cases where the documents did not explicitly reveal any illegality. We published classified information about NSA surveillance programs.
author: nickconfessore

text: The decision is and should be based on judgments about accuracy, factuality, news value, and the public interest. Those judgments have led The Times on numerous occasions to published stolen or classified information.
author: nickconfessore

text: All sources have motives. Most sources who provide non-public information have a reason for wanting that information public. But the decision to publish a story shouldn't depend on the source's motives.
author: nickconfessore

text: I sympathize with Amy's regrets about those stories. (See link below.) On a personal level, it feels invasive, especially knowing they were stolen. But I think on balance the decision to publish stories about the e-mails was correct.
author: nickconfessore

text: There were multiple discussions weighing this decision. Some of them Amy was not involved in, some of them neither of us was. My sense is that the paper gave it a lot of thought, collectively and individually. But this is just my personal take as a fellow reporter.
author: nickconfessore

text: As a former cubicle-mate of @amychozick and an author or co-author on some of the @nytimes coverage of the hacked Podesta and DNC e-mails, I have a different view of our paper's decision to publish stories based on those e-mails.

text: ICYMI: Our story, from yesterday evening, on how the government-approved Facebook auditor gave Facebook's privacy programs a clean bill of health after Facebook lost control of data for millions of users to Cambridge Analytica.
author: nickconfessore

text: The leaks are coming from inside the House.
author: nickconfessore

text: Basically, while it sounds like the FTC required a tough independent audit, what they've gotten in practice is something a lot weaker. An "assessment" that, PwC's documents indicate, is framed by the company being assessed.
author: nickconfessore

text: Also: the FTC's order technically requires that Facebook get an independent "assessment" of its privacy procedures. But unlike with an audit, where the independent person works off a set of accounting standards, the assessment indicates Facebook dictates how it will be assessed.
author: nickconfessore

text: It is pretty clear that Facebook, during that period, was not closely policing what app developers did with the data they got from Facebook. Which is problematic against the language of that decree.
author: nickconfessore

text: Discussion around Facebook's compliance with the FTC order has focused on question of user consent. But Facebook also had a broader responsibility: To identify potential risks to user data and implement "reasonable controls and procedures" to assess those risks.
author: nickconfessore

text: Hat tip to EPIC's @MarcRotenberg, who had also FOIAed for the assessments, and who let us know Wednesday that the redacted privacy assessments were sitting in plain sight.
author: nickconfessore

text:
The PwC assessment, covering 2/15-2/17, found that “Facebook’s privacy controls were operating with sufficient effectiveness to provide reasonable assurance to protect the privacy” of users.
Yet during that period, Facebook learned Cambridge had acquired its data.
author: nickconfessore

text: We FOIAed the privacy assessments, conducted by PricewaterhouseCoopers, last week. Turns out they were sitting on the FTC'S Web site.
author: nickconfessore

text: NEW: Auditors in charge of ensuring Facebook compliance with FTC privacy decree gave the company a clean bill of health even after Facebook lost control of a huge trove of user data obtained by Cambridge Analytica.

text:
Here's another thing to think about.
The bot economy simply does not function without the implicit permission of @Google and other search engines.
Devumi and its competitors live and die on SEO, pure and simple.
Without @Google, they are invisible.
author: nickconfessore

text: FWIW, we don’t think Twitter Audit is worth a can of beans. Whatever it is doing is not reliable as a metric. E.G., our fingerprint analysis indicates @AaronKleinShow has mostly bot followers, not mostly real ones. https://twitter.com/kfile/status/957699952695705600 …
author: nickconfessore

text: Most of these people (the well-mannered and forthright @JoeConchaTV was an exception) did not respond to our calls/emails. A few hung up on us.
author: nickconfessore

text: And we are only just beginning to grapple with it. Take a look and thanks for reading.
author: nickconfessore

text: The capacity for fraud and manipulation on these platforms is immense. We've seen that with fake news and Russian or Chinese propaganda. But the commercial and even merely cultural possibilities are kind of staggering.
author: nickconfessore

text: Some people buy followers out of simple vanity. (I'm guessing the billionaire @MichaelDell, who did not respond to requests for comment, is in this category.) But others are hoping to juice social media by convincing real people that their opinion or product is influential.
author: nickconfessore

text: A single small company in Florida, using a few dozen overseas contractors, sold 200 million followers, using a pool of 3.5 million bots. There are at least dozens of these companies -- not counting the botmaking criminal syndicates and intelligence agencies.
author: nickconfessore

text: (To its credit, @Twitter is arguably the most open of these platforms--the one with the biggest window into the black box. That's why a lot of bot research focuses on Twitter.)
author: nickconfessore

text: These platforms allow and permit a level of reality-manipulation that is simply not possible in the real world where we used to do all these things. And they are closed commercial spaces, technological black boxes, exempt from the First Amendment.
author: nickconfessore

text: But there's a lot of evidence that these platforms are riddled with an almost unfathomable amount of fraud and manipulation. It is an altered reality. Most of us have little idea how the things we are looking at end up on our screens.
author: nickconfessore

text: More and more of our lives are moving onto or mediated by social media platforms--our politics, the way we consume news and culture, how we are advertised to, how we find products and services.
author: nickconfessore

text: Some broader threaded thoughts on the topic of bots and online fraud, why you should care, and why @gabrieldance, @Rich_Harris + @cocteau and I spent months on "The Follower Factory."

text: One finding of our report on the black market in social media fraud: @Twitter does not proactively police or search for impersonation. Enforcement of their policy depends heavily on users' reporting. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/01/27/technology/social-media-bots.html …
author: nickconfessore

text:
A 17-year-old girl's Twitter profile was copied, faked, and sold--to hundreds businesses, porn stars, celebrities, and "influencers". We found tens of thousands of other victims, and evidence of far more. 
Inside social media's black market: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2018/01/27/technology/social-media-bots.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=photo-spot-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news …

text:
The rebels have bombers. Not too many. Very slow. Like, walking speed. (Why?) These bombers have bombs. In space. When the bombers are over a Star Destroyer, the bombs fall out of the bomber and go down.
In space. 
In zero gravity.
There is literally no reason for any of this.
author: nickconfessore

text: Why are they even chasing? People in this universe have talking robots, replacement hands, and hovertanks, but no guided munitions? Which brings me to Act 1.
author: nickconfessore

text:
The entire second act of this movie is a spaceship chase. In a universe with FTL travel and instantaneous communication. 
Why is the First Order chasing the Resistance at sublight? Just call a couple of Star Destroyers to head them off from the other direction.
author: nickconfessore

text: For one thing, apparently the two sides in this universe are each catastrophically incompetent. Every flag officer appears to be terrible at their job. Poe Dameron is a good fighter pilot but otherwise an idiot--a parody of a hothead.
author: nickconfessore

text: All in all, I think it's clear that Rogue One is the true inheritor of the best of Star Wars--the model for future movies. Episodes VII-VIII, not so much.
